title.narrative: Equality Through Legal Action

description.narrative: Equality Through Legal Action addresses discrimination and human rights violations in Lebanon based on immigration status, nationality, gender and sexuality. The intervention empowers victims to seek meaningful access to justice, while trying to bring about legal reform.
Change in commitment to Anti-Racism Movement by Legal Action Worldwide

title.narrative: Year 1 (Interim) Report

description.narrative: An overview of results, outcomes and outputs for the first year of the project.

condition.narrative: Refrain from activities undermining political autonomy of a state; refrain from conduct that is prohibited under Dutch law, including sexual harassment; refrain from offering or accepting gifts or remuneration from third parties that could be interpreted as an illegal or corrupt practice; ensure that no funds are used to provide support to individuals or groups associated with terrorism, directly or indirectly.

title.narrative: Outcome 3: Improved capacity of justice actors in the justice chain to address discrimination and inequality and to ensure the human rights of targeted communities are respected

System of legal aid referrals, oversight and adherence to human rights of detainees from targeted communities at pilot police station is perceived by users (police and detainees) as reducing discrimination against detainees from targeted communities

comment.narrative: Percentage of users (police and detainees) interviewed who perceive pilot system as reducing discrimination

title.narrative: Output 1.5 Conduct focus-group discussions with members of targeted communities to understand inequality and discrimination from the perspective of the most vulnerable community members
Number of focus-group discussions held

comment.narrative:
5 FGDs were held with migrant domestic workers. The sessions took place on March 23 (two sessions) and April 10 (two sessions) and May 20. A total of 39 participants, all women, participated in the focus groups, of the following nationalities: 7 Ethiopian, 3 Kenyan, 7 Sri Lankan, 3 Beninese, 2 Malagasy, 1 Togolese, 1 Cameroonian, 2 Ivorian and 13 Bangladeshi.
4 FGDs were held with members of the LGBTQI community. The sessions took place on February 17 (2 sessions) and February 23 (two sessions). A total of 26 participants took part in the discussions.
4 FGDs were held with members of the stateless community. The sessions took place online on March 5 (two sessions) and March 9 (2 sessions). A total of 30 stateless persons participated in the discussions (19 women and 11 men).

Four focus-group discussions were conducted, two in Beirut and two in Tripoli, gathering a total of 40 LGBTQI+ individuals and disaggregated as follows: 26 men (16 Lebanese, 7 Syrian, 2 Palestinian and 1 Iraqi), 9 transwomen (6 Lebanese and 3 Syrian), 4 women (2 Lebanese and 2 Syrian), and 1 transman (Syrian) to produce an advocacy briefing on discrimination against LGBTQI+ individuals in Lebanon.

Legal assistance: 27 cases
Counselling: 13 cases 5 migrant domestic workers: Cases included unpaid wages, confiscated passports and confiscated personal items.
7 LGBTQI+ individuals: Cases included blackmail and threats through dating applications and verbal and physical abuse.
1 stateless individual: Case of civil registration.
Mediation: 8 cases 8 migrant domestic workers: Cases included confiscated passports, unpaid wages, “tanazol” (sponsorship release) and criminal complaints of theft.
Civil documentation: 6 cases 6 migrant domestic workers: Cases on marriage and birth registration.

title.narrative: Outcome 1: Discrimination and inequality are addressed through the provision of quality legal aid to targeted communities
Percentage of beneficiaries of legal representation and assistance who report that it resulted in a beneficial outcome

comment.narrative: In the first year of the project, LAW has provided legal representation and assistance to 153 beneficiaries. LAW surveyed 17 beneficiaries for satisfaction in August 2021. According to the survey, 94% of respondents (16 out of 17 persons) reported that the legal aid resulted in a beneficial outcome. Although this is an extremely positive indication of the quality and impact of the legal aid provided, final conclusions must be deferred until a larger, more representative sample of beneficiaries has been surveyed. LAW will continue to monitor and measure this indicator in the second year of the project.

title.narrative: Output 2.3 File strategic litigation cases and design and implement complementary strategic advocacy strategy
Number of strategic litigation cases filed in the Lebanese court system

comment.narrative: On October 8, 2020, LAW filed a criminal complaint before the first investigative judge in Baabda, Mount Lebanon, on behalf of a 38-year-old former migrant domestic worker from Ethiopia. LAW’s case argues slavery, slave trading, trafficking in persons, forced labour, deprivation of liberty, withholding personal documents, racial discrimination, gender discrimination and torture. The defendants are the client’s former sponsor (kafeel) and recruiter. This case constitutes the first request in Lebanon for a criminal investigation into the treatment of a migrant domestic worker by her sponsor and recruiter. The first hearing in the case took place on October 19, 2021. The defendants did not attend the hearing. The second hearing was set for February 2022.

Number of outreach visits held

comment.narrative:
Outreach meetings by target group: 1. 2. LGBTQI: 4 (28 persons reached) 5/2/2021: 7 persons (1 woman, 4 men, 1 genderfluid, 1 agender) 5/2/2021: 8 persons (5 women, 3 non-binary) 5/2/2021: 7 persons (2 women, 3 men, 1 genderfluid, 1 agender) 10/2/2021: 6 persons (4 women, 1 man, 1 genderfluid)
3. Stateless: 4 (23 persons reached) 28/1/2021: 7 persons (5 women, 2 men) 10/2/2021: 5 men 18/2/2021: 5 persons (3 women, 2 men) 4/3/2021: 6 persons (3 women, 3 men)

title.narrative: Output 1.2 Community leaders are capacity built to become advocates
Number of community leaders trained to become advocates for equal access to justice

comment.narrative:
The first advocacy training was conducted on April 24, 2021 in Beirut for migrant domestic workers. The training was attended by 17 (2 Ethiopian, 2 Nepalese, 1 Sri Lankan, 3 Philippine, 2 Nigerian, 1 Ivorian, 1 Beninese and 5 Cameroonian)
A second training was held on May 21, 2021 in Beirut for the LGBTQI community. The training was attended by 11 persons (3 ciswomen, 6 cismen, 1 transgender, 1 gender-fluid; 5 Lebanese, 2 Syrian, 1 Palestinian, 1 Egyptian, 1 American, 1 stateless)

The third and final advocacy training was given to 10 stateless community leaders on August 27, 2021, and was attended by 6 stateless women and 4 stateless men. Attendees included members of both "maktoumi al qayd" (unregistered) and "qayd ad dars" (under consideration) stateless categories.

title.narrative: Specific Objective: To address serious discrimination and human rights abuse and violations based on immigration status, nationality, gender or sexuality in Lebanon and empower victims and survivors to meaningfully participate in effective access to justice and legal change
Percentage of victims and survivors interviewed who receive legal information, assistance and/or representation report feeling empowered by their engagement with the project

comment.narrative: The intervention seeks to empower members of the target groups to seek access to justice. Project beneficiaries who have received legal information, assistance and representation were surveyed by LAW in August 2021, at the end of the first year of the project, and asked whether their engagement with the project has helped them feel more empowered. A total of 54 participants were surveyed about empowerment, including 37 participants who received legal information and 17 participants who received legal assistance or representation.

title.narrative: Output 3.3 Create a model system of legal aid referrals, oversight and adherence to human rights of detainees from targeted communities at pilot police station (Hbeish)
Number of legal aid referrals made by police for detained members of targeted communities

comment.narrative: In July 2021, two cases were referred to LAW’s lawyers concerning detainees at Hbeish police station in need of legal counselling.

In this quarter, LAW’s lawyer visited the Hbeish detention centre and received nine cases of detainees; seven were non-responsive to regular and WhatsApp phone calls, and one did not currently require legal aid.

title.narrative: Number of police trained on human rights of targeted communities

comment.narrative: Five training sessions were organised for 17 police officers of the Anti-Human Trafficking and Morals Protection Bureau at Hbeish police station via Zoom on August 16, 23 and 30 and on September 3 and 8, 2021. The officers were 3 Lebanese women and 14 Lebanese men.

title.narrative: Output 3.2 Design and deliver tailored capacity-building programmes to partner lawyers, police, prosecutors and judges
Number of capacity-building programmes delivered

comment.narrative: Five training sessions were organised for 17 police officers of the Anti-Human Trafficking and Morals Protection Bureau at Hbeish police station via Zoom on August 16, 23 and 30 and on September 3 and 8, 2021. The officers were 3 Lebanese women and 14 Lebanese men.

title.narrative: Number of individuals who have received capacity-building programmes

comment.narrative: 63 lawyers (45 Lebanese women, 1 Syrian woman and 17 Lebanese men) attended the training on international human rights legal instruments at the Lancaster Hotel in Beirut on the 4th and 18th of March 2022 and at the Miramar Hotel in Tripoli on the 24th of March 2022.

Five training sessions were organised for 17 police officers of the Anti-Human Trafficking and Morals Protection Bureau at Hbeish police station via Zoom on August 16, 23 and 30 and on September 3 and 8, 2021. The officers were 3 Lebanese women and 14 Lebanese men.

title.narrative: Output 3.1 Conduct joint capacity assessments with partner lawyers, police, prosecutors and judges
Number of joint capacity assessments endorsed by relevant institution / group of justice actors

comment.narrative: A capacity assessment of police officers has been completed, and was used by lawyers to inform the design of the capacity-building activity (Output 3.2). The assessment asked about officers’ knowledge of human rights conventions like CEDAW, CAT, ICCPR, ICESCR and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, as well the rights of detainees under Lebanese law.

Prior to 3 capacity building events for lawyers and prosecutors, a needs assessment survey was circulated among participants. The results found significant gaps in their understanding of international human rights conventions.

title.narrative: Output 2.1 Train lawyers on strategic litigation and creative legal solutions
Number of lawyers who participate in training on strategic litigation and creative legal solutions

comment.narrative: 54 lawyers and paralegals trained on strategic litigation concepts and methods (31 Lebanese women and 23 Lebanese men)

title.narrative: Output 2.2 Identify, research and compile strategic litigation case files
Number of strategic litigation case files compiled

comment.narrative: In April 2019, LAW received a call from an organisation working in the humanitarian field explaining the case of a 38-year-old migrant domestic worker from Ethiopia. LAW’s legal team compiled all relevant files related to the submission of this strategic litigation case. For this case, LAW had two options: 1) to approach a civil court to claim unpaid wages, or 2) to approach a criminal court with a complaint of human trafficking, slavery and forced labour. With the client’s consent, LAW decided to initiate a criminal lawsuit.

title.narrative: Number of legal opinions drafted
Outcome 2: Legal change reducing inequality and discrimination is precipitated through strategic litigation
Number of unjust laws or laws incompatible with Lebanon's human rights obligations challenged by strategic litigation
Overall Objective: To achieve equality before the law, attitudinal change and legal redress for individuals and groups who are discriminated against in Lebanon
Legal change occurs in relation to the legal framework applied to migrant domestic workers, LGBTQI persons, statelessness or gender inequality

comment.narrative: There has been no new legislation in the timeframe of the project addressing the legal framework applied to the projects’ target groups, namely migrant domestic workers, LGBTQI persons, or stateless persons. However, in December 2020, parliament passed a law criminalising sexual harassment, providing a broad and clear of the latter and including sexual harassment in the workplace and online. In addition, the new law made amendments to Law 293 on domestic violence, broadening the scope and definition of the latter. This change potentially benefits members of all of the project’s target groups. In addition, there have been administrative changes concerning migrant domestic workers. In September 2020, an updated standard contract for migrant domestic workers was adopted by the Ministry of Labour. The contract included new protections for migrant domestic workers, including a weekly rest day, overtime pay, sick pay, annual leave, and the national minimum wage. However, a complaint brought forward by the Syndicate of Owners of Recruitment Agencies in Lebanon (SORAL) led to a preliminary decision by the Higher State Council, the country’s highest administrative court, to suspend implementation of the new contract until a final decision had been reached by the court. Despite this setback, it is evident that there is initiative among some stakeholders, such as the Ministry of Labour, to ensure fair working conditions for migrant domestic workers. In February 2021, the Directorate General of General Security issued a decree pertaining to migrant domestic workers who leave their place of work. Previously, employers commonly pressed false charges of theft against the migrant domestic worker in such situations. As per the new regulations, employers can inform General Security that the domestic worker has left in an administrative procedure, which removes any civil responsibilities the employer has towards the migrant domestic worker, without resulting in punitive measures for the migrant domestic worker. LAW will continue to monitor this change and advocate for ending the Kafala system and modern slavery, as well as the elimination of gender-based violence, as part of its mission in Lebanon, with the understanding that these legal and social changes may occur outside of the timeframe of the project.
